terms.term: Define tidal volume
terms.definition: Volume of air inspired and expired per normal breath (ml)

terms.term: Define frequency
terms.definition: Breaths taken per minute

terms.term: Equation linking tidal freq and minute ventilation
terms.definition: Minute ventilation (l/min) = tidal volume (ml) x freq (b/min)

terms.term: Average values at rest sub max , max
terms.definition:
Rest: f-15 x tv-500ml = 7.5l/m
Sub max: 20x 600=12l/min
Max: 70 x 3l =210 L

terms.term: Describe the pathway of air
terms.definition:
Nose and mouth
Pharynx 
Larynx 
Trachea 
Bronchi
Bronchioles 
Alveoli

terms.term: Describe the mechanics of breathing at rest
terms.definition:
Inspiration:
External intercostals contract causing teh ribs to move up and out
Diaphragm contracts and flattens 
These increases the volume of the thoracic cavity 
Increased volume causes decreased pressure inside the lungs 
This forces air into the lungs due to the pressure gradient between inside the lugs and in the atmosphere (higher)
Air is sucked in to create an equilibrium 

Expiration: 
External intercostals relax causing ribs to move in and downwards
Diaphragm relaxes and domes
These decrease volume of lungs/thoracic cavity 
Decreased volume causes increased pressure inside lungs 
This forces air out due to pressure graduent between inside lungs and in atmosphere (lower)
Air is forced out to create an equilibrium

terms.term: ,mechanics of breathing during exercise
terms.definition:
Inspiration:
-The external intercostals contract with greater force than at rest, pulling the ribcage and lungs upwards and outwards further than at rest, alongside the greater forcefully contracting and flattening diaphragm. 
-These muscles contracting with greater force increase the volume of the lungs and the thoracic cavity more than at rest. 
-The sternocleidomastoid is recruited to aid the thoracic cavity’s volume increase with greater force/at a faster rate. 
-This increase in volume decreases the pressure in the lungs more than at rest, which sucks more air in at a faster rate than at rest to create equilibrium. 

Expiration: becomes active process
Diaphragm and external intercostals relax causing
Rectus abdominus contracts to help pul diaphragm up with greater force than at rest 
Larger increase in pressure inside lungs than at rest 
Larger pressure gradient 
More air than at rest is forced out of the lungs to create an equilibrium

terms.term: Name 5 spirometry characteristics
terms.definition:
Tidal volume
Inspiratory/expiratory reserve volume 
Vital capacity 
Total lung capacity 
Residual volume 
Functional residual capacity

terms.term: Define tidal volume
terms.definition: Amount of air inspired or expired per breath

terms.term: Define breathing rate
terms.definition: Number of inspirations / breaths per minute

terms.term: Define minute ventilation
terms.definition:
Volume of air inspired/expired per minute  
MV=TV x f

terms.term: Values of TV, BR, MV
terms.definition:
TV: 500ml
BR: 12-15 breaths 
MV: 7,500ml/min

terms.term: How does tidal volume change during exercise and why
terms.definition:
Increases in proportion to exercise intensity at sub-max intensity (up to 3L) as more air is required to keep up with increased respiration rate and subsequent increased demand for 02 
Reaches a plateau during sub-mac because high BR doesn’t allow enough time/effort for maximal inspiration/expirations
Peaks and troughs get taller and get closer and closer together

terms.term: How does exercise affect breathing rate
terms.definition:
Increases in proportion to exercise until max breaths per minute is reached (50-60br/min)
Plateaus during sub-mac when supply of 02 reaches demand of working muscles

terms.term: Effect of exercise on minute volume
terms.definition: BR and TV both increase to meet the increase in demand of o2 supply to working muscles, resulting in minute volume increasing becasue TV x BR = MV which means MV is directly proportional to both TV and BR.

terms.term: Define internal gaseous exchange
terms.definition: Exchange of gases at the muscles, between the muscle tissue and capillaires.

terms.term: Define external gaseous exchange
terms.definition: Exchange of gases in the lungs, between alveoli and capillaries

terms.term: Explain the process of gaseous exchange at the alveoli
terms.definition:
O2:
Partial pressure of o2 in alveoli is high 
“” in capillaries is low 
Causes diffusion gradient 
Results in o2 diffusing from high (in alveoli) to low (in capillaries) concentration across the alveoli cell membrane
Association occurs when o2 molecules bind to the haemoglobin on red blood cells until they are highly saturated 
After this, equilibrium is reached when the partial pressure of o2 in alveoli and capillaries are equal 
O2 is transported through the bloodstream to muscles for respiration 

CO2:
Pco2 in capillaries is high
Pco2 in alveoli is low
Causes diffusion gradient Results
Results in co2 diffusing from high (capillaries ) to low (alveoli)across alveolus cell membrane Association occurs
After diffusion, equilibrium is reached due to equal Pco2 in alveoli and capillaries 
CO2 is expired as a waste product

terms.term: Explain the process of gaseous exchange at the muscles cells
terms.definition:
O2:
Partial pressure of oxygen in the capillaries is high 
Partial pressure of oxygen in muscles is low 
This creates a diffusion gradient 
This causes diffusion of oxygen from high in the capillaries to low concentration in the muscles
Oxygen dissociates from haemoglobin on red blood cells and diffuses to associate to myoglobin in muscles to allow for respiration 
Haemoglobin is now unsaturated and ready for more association when it circulate back to the lungs in the bloodstream
After diffusion equilibrium is reached as the partial pressure of oxygen in the capillaries and muscles are equal.

CO2:
Partial pressure of CO2 in muscles is high and low in capillaries
This creates a diffusion gradient causing diffusion of carbon dioxide from high to low concentration from muscles to capillaries
This leads to equilibrium being reached as partial pressure of carbon dioxide is equal in muscles and capillaries
Diffusion of carbon dioxide occurs in order to remove carbon dioxide is a waste product of aerobic respiration

terms.term: What is the effect of exercise on gas exchange?
terms.definition:
External:
During exercise muscles use more oxygen due to increased respiration rates to supply the body with energy for exercise by breaking down glucose
It produces much more carbon dioxide as well as a waste product of this increased respiration rate 
Therefore, the partial pressure of oxygen Returning to the alveoli in the capillaries is much lower than at rest and the partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the capillaries is much higher than at rest
This causes a steeper concentration /diffusion gradient which causes a faster rate of diffusion of oxygen from the alveoli into the capillaries and carbon dioxide from the capillaries into the alveoli
Which overall causes an increased rate of gases exchange

Internal: 
More oxygen is required in the muscle tissue for increased respiration rates to sustain exercise 
Increase in body temperature and increased acidity increases the rate of oxygen dissociation which increases the rate of gases exchange between the capillaries and the muscle tissue because oxygen can detach from haemoglobin quicker and therefore diffuse into the muscle tissue quicker
Also a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen within the muscle caused by increased respiration as well as an increase in the partial pressure of carbon oxide in the capillaries caused by increased respiration steep in the diffusion gradient causing diffusion to occur quicker which causes an rate of gases exchange.

terms.term: Factors assisting the speed of diffusion from the lungs into the bloodstream
terms.definition:
Large surface of alveoli
Strong affinity between haemoglobin and oxygen 
Alveoli respiratory membrane is very thin 
Alveoli and capillary respiratory membranes are permeable 
Large surface area of alveoli 
Concentration gradient
Layer of moisture between alveoli and capillary enhances uptake of oxygen leading to more chance of association
Slow velocity of blood through capillaries 
Lots of capillaries in lungs, large surface area for diffusion  (capillarisation)

terms.term: Factors existing the speed of diffusion from muscles to the blood stream
terms.definition:
Myoglobin has a high affinity for oxygen
High concentration gradient 
Slow velocity of blood through capillaries 
Capillary wall one cell thick - short distance to travel
Semi permeable capillary walls 
Large number of capillaries near muscles -high surface area for diffusion

terms.term: What are the two sections of the respiratory control centre? (RCC)
terms.definition: Inspiratory and expiratory Centre

terms.term: Describe the control of breathing at rest
terms.definition:
The inspiration Centre sends an impulses to the diaphragm via the front nerve and intercostal muscles by the intercostal nerve causing them to contract
These muscles increase the volume of the lungs by pulling them up and outwards increasing the volume of the thoracic cavity causing a decrease in pressure and a subsequent pressure gradient which causes air to be sucked into the lungs to create an equilibrium between the pressure inside the lungs and in the atmosphere 
After two seconds, the inspiratory stopped sending these nerve impulses to respiratory muscles and the external intercostal and diaphragm relax 
This decreases the volume of the lungs thus increasing pressure and forcing air out of the lungs due to the pressure gradient in order to maintain equilibrium between the lung pressure and the atmospheric pressure 
The expiratory Centre is inactive during rest

terms.term: Describe the control of breathing during exercise
terms.definition:
During exercise breaths become more rapid and deeper 
Chemoreceptors detect an increase in blood acidity Thermoreceptors detect an increase in body temperature proprioceptors detect an increase in movement and they all inform the inspiratory centre to increase nerve stimulation to the respiratory muscles (via the phrenic and intercostal nerve)
The inspiration Centre stimulates the pectoralis minor and sternocleidomastoid muscles to assist with inspiration
Baroreceptors inform the expiratory Centre on the extent of lung inflation, when this becomes too high the expiratory Centre becomes active and stimulates the intercostal muscles and rectus abdominous to assist in expiration.

terms.term: Where are chemo receptors found and what do they do?
terms.definition: They found in the aorta and carotid arteries and they detect blood acidity

terms.term: What are Thermo receptors? Where are they found? And what do they do?
terms.definition: Generally found in the blood they detect body temperature

terms.term: What do proprioceptor do and where are they found?
terms.definition: Found in muscles and joints and detect movement

terms.term: What do baroreceptors do? And where are they found?
terms.definition: Found in blood vessels and lung tissues and detect blood pressure and the stretch of lungs during inflation

terms.term: Describe the long-term effects of training on lung function
terms.definition:
Increases in lung volumes:
Total longer capacity remain remains unchanged
Title volume increases slightly during high intensity exercise 
Vital capacity increases slightly by taking a little bit away from residual volume 
These slight increases occur due to stronger respiratory muscle muscles /hypertrophy due to training

Improve transport of respiratory gases :
Prolonged training causes more total blood volume due to an increase in total blood plasma  = lower blood viscosity = lower blood pressure
More red blood cells  = more haemoglobin
This causes increased rate of oxygen delivery to muscles and removal of carbon dioxide therefore increased gas exchange can occur

More efficient gaseous exchange at the alveoli and muscle tissue:
Increase capillarisation in muscles and lungs = great opportunity for gases exchanged due to larger surface area
Better blood flow to lungs and an increase in minute ventilation
Results in increased external respiration

Improved uptake of oxygen by muscles:
Improvement in maximum oxygen uptake (VO2 max)
More myoglobin in muscles
Larger a-vo2 difference

terms.term: How is oxygen transported in the blood?
terms.definition:
97% by haemoglobin through association
3% dissolved in blood plasma

terms.term: Define haemoglobin
terms.definition: Iron rich protein in red blood cells which can chemically combine with four oxygen molecules

terms.term: Define oxyhaemoglobin
terms.definition: Oxygen combined with haemoglobin after association

terms.term: Describe haemoglobin saturation in the Venus blood leaving the muscle
terms.definition: Low haemoglobin saturation because a high percentage of oxygen has dissociated and refused into muscle tissue

terms.term: Define the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve
terms.definition: Shows the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen and the percentage saturation of haemoglobin

terms.term: Suggest where points a,b and c would be in the body and explain why
terms.definition:
A: found in the muscle tissue at rest
B: found in the muscle tissue during exercise because the partial pressure of oxygen decreases the haemoglobin more readily dissociate with oxygen releasing it to the muscle tissue
C: found in the lungs during gaseous exchange because at the lungs the partial pressure of oxygen is very high so blood leaving the lungs is almost 100% saturated

terms.term: What is the Bohr shift?
terms.definition: The shift of the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve to the right because during exercise the dissociation of oxygen from haemoglobin occurs more readily. This is due to more carbon dioxide and an increase in lactic acid levels so blood increases during exercise causing a decreased haemoglobin affinity for oxygen as well as increased body temperature which causes oxygen to dissociate quicker when blood is warmer.
